titleStmt.title: M54, 9 of 11. [Anon: The road led to the old graves...]. Typescript fragment, 8 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 9 of 11. [Anon: The road led to the old graves...]. Typescript fragment, 8 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified in the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: The road led to the old graves, to the stones where the old pagan English had offered sacrifice. The peasants still went that way, in spir ng (spring), summer and winter, by instinct. The old Gods stil (still) lay hidden beneath the new. Even if they were now nameless, it was to txxxxx do them homage, to win crops, husbands, health, that the peasants came amxmxmxmxmxmxm in spring summer and winter.

It is the printing press that we owe their preservation. "After that I had accomplished and finsihed (finished) divers histories" wrote in 41470 (1470) in the preface to the , "many noble and divers gentlemen of this realm of England came and demanded me many and oft times ..... to imprint the history of the said noble king and conqueror , and of his knights with the history of the and of the death and ending of the said Arthur." The twenty one books of the Morte DArthur preserve what lay benea th (beneath), Ther (there) we tap into the deep reservoir of common belief that lay behind the peasant and the noble. The legnd (legend) was still alive in the nineteenth century. "...folks do say" said a peasant at that on the night of the full moon King Arthus (Arthur) and his men ride round the hill, and their horses are shod with silver..." A silver horseshoe, says, was found in time at . It is in pages that we hear the voice of anon murmuring in the mind of King and Queen and peasant, They remembered how the old King

and his knights went their ways through the wild woods seek ing adventure. When himself doubted. Nosuch a man, he objected, had ever lived. But the nobles were positive, they said that you could see skull at and the at and in "in other places sword and many other things.

The book itself represents scepticism, and the nobles faith. It is half fable, half fact. There is , and and ; there is the and . But the roads lead past London to castles where Knights lie in prison; down the roads ride Queens on white mules; turns suddenly to stone; and a hand rises from a lake holding . In the canfdour (candour) with wh h (which) it is told, it is a childs story. But the the child has lived for centuries. It has not our pers spective. The inventories, the catalogues are mad (made) with a childs partciularity (particularity). The clear eye sees definitely and without exaggeration. Beauty is in the thing itself, not i in the writers manipulation. So he went in and searched
chamber from chamber to chamber, and found his bed, but she was not there; then Balin lookedinto a fxmx little garden and under a laurel tree he saw her lie upon a quilt of green samite and a kmight (knight) with her, and under their heads grass and herbs."

But It is not a childs world; it is a world before self consciousness has raised i s (its) mirror. The men and women are
angualr (angular), gigantic; freed from somthing (something) impure; yet sin tarnished, acqauinted (acquainted) with sorrow, corrupt, in the midst of this fresh landscape, remembering,

We lose our bearings following these Knights and ladies; to live in t is (this) prehistroic (prehistoric) land we must sehd (shed) many habits of thoght (thought); but after all it is not an unreal world; a fabricated world; it still exists in us, deep sunk, savage, primitive; m remembered.

Of the writer, nothing is knonw (known). He is not [illeg.] emerged
disnctin c (distinct) from hsi ook (his book). It is still the anonymous voice speaking anonysmously (anonymously) generally hat (that) the lsiener (listener) already
hald (half) knows, or rmemebers (remembers). The lsiener (listener) hears the voice partly in himself; as it comes from the man at the back door who has been travelling in trange (strange) parts acrsoos (across) the marsh across the flood to r mind (remind) the peasnt (peasant) and the noble of the world that was before them. And still the dream lingered; for the peasnts (peasants)

In the great house and the cottage this half articulate voice murmured of old gods a d (and) kings and inihgts (knights) The well and the tree were still haunted. King Arthur the foreste s (foresters) said in the thirteenth cnetury (century), ;;;"about
noon or midngiht (midnight) when the moon is sufulland (full and) shining [we?] often see an array of hunters with dogs and sound of horns who ins anser (answer) to the enwuirers (enquirers) says
yhat (that) they are of the hosuehold (household) and fellowship of
King Art ur (Arthur)." Along the roads from town to town from house to ouse (house), came the minstresl (minstrels) the jugglers and the impudent bardes. whil (While) for those who could read it, Caxtons book tol (told) the old stories set out in print.
then late (later) the instinct to enact, to impersonate

hat () they believed imagined came into existence. Even the King and Queen shared the it, and must have their actors or minstersl (minstrels) to vie (give) body tongue to this hidden insticnt (instinct) [illeg.]. The acror (actor) was despied (despised); did he not make use of his body? and did he not, feeling himself an otcast (outcast), use the outiders (outsiders) privilege of
irrepsoneible (irresponsible) mockery? But the Kings and Queens tolerated him, as to rate (tolerate) those who say what we are too proud to admit. Even the church men had to a re aware that the Gids (Gods) that he worshipped wre (were) not theirs had to yeild (yield) to him; or to make use of his gift to If they could they constrained the c ors (actors) and the da cers (dancers) t (to) put off their l evea (leaves) na d (and) bells and dress themselves as the sacred figures in a miracle play. But the churchmen did their best to prvent (prevent) them.

The printing press brought the past into existence. It also brought into existence, seen agoanst (against) the back
rgound (ground) of the past. And it brough by degrees the indivual (individual) into existence--the indi idual (individual) who looking back sees himself the man who is separate from his book. against the background. The individual emerges at last. He is a chronicler and the [illeg.]His name is ; it is also . Harrison tells us that he has books; and a mastiff; and digs i (in) the ground for Roman coins. He tells us that he has nev (never) been more than forty miles from in . The individual, still much sumplified (simplified), but sxxxxx no longer nameless, emrges (emerges). He is losing his ambiguity. the present is becoming visible. Harrison sees the present moment (15 ) against the settled orderly past. The present looks degenrate (degenerate), raw, against that past.

It was at half past two in th (the) afternoon that the trumpets dounded (sounded) and the flag flew over the Theatre. The playhouse was open to the sky. A penny or twopence was the price of a seat. There was no scenery; but the walls were painted; and the actors were richly dressed, according to one spectator in the cast off robes of the nobles, sold by their servants. What other amusement as (was) there in the afternoon, for the gentlement of the court, txxx of the Inns of Court, for the numbers of captains and soldiers about London? Only the amusements that Latimer deplored; carding, dicing, gaming, following of xmxmxmxmxmx harlots and drinking. The rivxmxmxmxmx audience came from the drowded (crowded) festering little streets txxxx round where the buried smelt so strong. The river was crowded with wherries ferrying them across: The riverside people depnded (depended) upon their fares. The flag flew; the trumpets dsounded (sounded); and
audince (audience) crowded into the open playhouse, clustered round the stage; and heard:
Brother Cosroe, I find myself aggrieved, Yet insufficient yto (to) express the same; For it requires a great and thundering speech

At last the voice speaks from the actual body of one man. xmxmxmxmxm.And the wolrd (world) became visible. Egypt, Libya; Persia; Greece. It unrolled itself time; and the armies of gr at (great) Kings; and plains; and palaces. There is no abstraction any longer. All is visible tangible, audible. Txmxmxmxmxm
ords (Words) seem to swell and stretch and tumble over themslves (themselves) in the effort to give body to this vast universe. They can scarcely contain all they would bring forward.
The sprung (spring) is hindered by your smothering host, For neither rain can fall upon the earth, Nor sun reflex his virtuous beams thereon, The ground is mantled with such multitudes.

Abrtactions (Abstractions) withdraw themselves. Axmxmxxx The Kings and Emperors stride forth, palpable, coloured, strident. The ae They are hewn, mob- monstrous, brilliantly painted; but they movel they speak. They emerge like great moths,
stillcreased (still creased) and damp, shaking their wings in splendid
aburd (absurd) hyperboles and raptures and The great names crash like cymbals

tell him, xmxmxx thy Lord the Turkish Emperor,
Dre d (Dread) Lord of Afric, Eruope (Europe) and Asia, Great king and conqueor (conqueror) of Greacia (Graecia), The ocean, Terrene, and the coal-black sea....

It is bombast, it is pagenatry (pageantry); it is hyperbole. And yet
pusis ant (puissant), Words mout (mount); pile on top of each ther (other); surpass common sense; clah (clash) and rebound:

W se (Whose) eyes are brighter than the lamps of Haevan (Heaven), And speech more pl sant (pleasant) than sweet harmony! that with thy looks canst clclear (clear) the datkemed (darkened) sky, And calm the rage of thundering Jupiter...

He is beyond the provinces of plain pseech (speech), revelling in some untouched garden of untouched blooms; picking plaucking (plucking) words, and strewing them. There is no shadow; all is gold and urple (purple). Yet in the very pitch and height of this extravagance, xmxmxmxmx he veers,
So poets say my lord.
An (And) tis a pretty toy to be a poet..
So distended with rapture, the tune changes effectively.

Could he stop, he would cutdeeper. But there is no pause; no shadow. The pagenat (pageant) [illeg.]. The horses neigh. Kings and Empeors (Emperors) emerge. Battles are fought. Blood flows. And all over this multitidionous (multitudinous) splendour broods agedy (tragedy) xmxmxmmxmxmxxx We forbode. We behold the thing as We [illeg.] there spectacle. There is the end to come. Meanwhile, let us boas (boast) and triumph.

Our souls, whose faculties can comprehend The wondrous architecture of the world, And measure very wandering planets course Still climbing after knowlede (knowledge) infinute (infinite), And always moving as the restless spe eres (spheres), Well us to wear ourselves, and never rest...

That is the meldy (melody) the marching song of this brave
septacle (spectacle). And yet, as if the poet slipped the noose of his audiences, releved (relieved) himself of its pressure for one moment, we hear: amid the so nding (sounding) brass:

What is beautym (beauty,) saith my sufferings, then? If all the pens that ever poets held Had fed the feelingsx (feelings) of their masters' thoughts,
.....
If all these had made one poems riod (period), And all combined in b auty's (beauty's) worthiness, Yet should there hover in their estless (restless) heads one thought, one wxxxxxxx grace, one wonder, at the least,
Which into words no virtue can digest

It is a break; a [illeg.] out of keeping; to be recalled at once a sign that the dramatist is separate from the anony ous (anonymous) play maker; There is no little language to put on Kings lips; so that he cannot as yet amalgamante (amalgamate) naturally the thought and the action. The audience, the shopr keeprs (shopkeepers) apprentices insoored (ensured) not relfection (reflection) blood [illeg.], but action,
movemnt (movement). The play is still partly the work of the audience; of the undifferentiated gluttonous word greedy mass. It is inspired by the common voice, demanding great names, simple outl nes (outlines); clamour and virtory (victory) and death; not the singe (single) subtlety of one soul. Refelction (Reflection) breaks off from
ction (action); there is no harml sing ([harmonising? harming?]) common speech.
